text: today on x cast the Republican race for
2012 focuses on Newt Gingrich and Mitt
Romney a month before the Iowa caucuses
the US unemployment rate unexpectedly
drops to eight point six percent the
lowest level in two and a half years we
need to keep that growth goal and
despite decades of war and environmental
destruction in Afghanistan scientists
have found several large cat species
which may be evidence of a healthier
than expected ecosystem we're finally
getting some clarity in the Republican
presidential primary race with Herman
Cain's flame out this is now coming down
to a two-man race between Mitt Romney
and Newt Gingrich and one of the big
questions over the four weeks between
now and the first voting in Iowa in
early January is whether mr. Gingrich
can develop enough of a campaign
organization enough momentum and a clear
enough message to compete there in New
Hampshire and South Carolina after that
Gingrich has been running so far largely
on his very strong debate performances
but now he has to turn to a different
kind of challenge which is actually
turning voters out that's a particular
challenge in Iowa where the caucuses
demand a level of organization that he
really hasn't had so far but there's
also the question of if he does well
enough to survive those first early
States is he going to be able to compete
with Mitt Romney in terms of money and
organization for what could be a long
primary season thank you Mitt Romney by
contrast has a much more traditional and
expensive campaign operation he has the
money the people on the ground the
advertising the whole campaign
infrastructure the Gingrich doesn't have
but Romney has been unable to seal the
deal in polls he still can't really
break through twenty five percent and
party elders the establishment Governors
members of Congress are still holding
back
even its Republicans prepare to begin
the voting the economic climate seems to
be changing a little bit the new
unemployment numbers showing the
unemployment rate ticking down job
creation ticking up a little bit all
this could be good news for President
Obama the economy has clearly been the
biggest anchor around his chances of a
second term this morning we learned that
our economy added another 140,000
private-sector jobs in November the
unemployment rate went down and despite
some strong headwinds this year the
American economy is now created in the
private sector jobs for the past 21
months in a row the unemployment report
today was surprisingly good the rate
went down to eight point six percent
from nine percent that's the lowest
level since early 2009 and it's much
much lower than it was only a few months
ago that number comes from what they
call a household survey they call up a
lot of people and ask who in your
household has a job who in your
household wants a job and they compile
those numbers there's also another
survey which is the survey of employers
asking how many people are working for
you this month that survey showed
120,000 more people working that was a
little disappointing compared to the
last couple of months but still much
stronger than it was this summer but
every month that survey seems to get
revised upward as they get more data now
obviously they're not good but if you
look at the recent changes what you see
is that you're getting more jobs among
people who really needed jobs the
unemployment rate for college graduates
is 4.4% which is just where it was last
month is up a little bit in fact over a
few months ago but the rate for the
lesser educated has been coming down
that's really good news another piece of
good news is the number of people who
are really long-term unemployed seems to
be declining it's still very high higher
than we'd ever seen it before this cycle
but it's coming down so all in all this
jobs report looks really good
and decades of war have degraded much of
Afghanistan's natural environment but
there are some positive signs this is
Rachel nuwer for the New York Times
Peter zoller is a biologist with the
Wildlife Conservation Society he runs
the only wildlife conservation program
in Afghanistan the image of Afghanistan
is one of conflict blasted landscape
almost like the dark side of the moon
but in reality it's it's still a pretty
vibrant place from the biodiversity
standpoint in the past few years zahler
has discovered several species of large
cats thought to be extinct in the region
so this is a shot of a very healthy
possibly mail persian leopard the
persian leopard was actually considered
to be extinct in this region so we're
very excited about the fact that we've
managed to find them there because big
cats are at the top of the food chain
their presence is a sign of a healthy
ecosystem we've managed to collect a
total of about 68 camera trap photos of
snow leopard suggesting that there's
still a very robust population of this
animal left in Afghanistan they're only
somewhere between three thousand and
seven thousand animals left on the
planet this links is I believe the first
record of links in this region of the
Central Highlands and Afghanistan it's a
species that's found across Europe and
into the Himalayas the environment here
is threatened by overuse and the cats
are also a target for poachers zollars
camera traps capture more than just
animals in action here unfortunately is
a picture of one of the threats to all
of this wildlife which is a shot of
local people very likely poachers moving
across the landscape ironically its
international soldiers and aid workers
who provide a market for poachers buying
wildlife goods as souvenirs dollars
group is educating foreigners and
working with local Rangers to raise
awareness one of the things that I like
about this image is that a quick glance
at it gives you the impression of the
sort of classic image that you see of
local insurgents about to fire a rocket
launcher and then you look at it more
closely and you realize it's a spotting
scope and binoculars and these are
actually wildlife researchers there are
nine cat species native to Afghanistan
the same number as in sub-saharan Africa
but while national parks are long
established in Africa there is just one
newly open park in Afghanistan it's
called bandy Amir it's a real point of
pride for the Afghan people as not only
just a sign of their country's efforts
in terms of reconstruction recovery but
as a part of becoming a member of the
international community
